newsitem.title: USA: CBOT soyoil ends sharply higher, meal mostly down.
newsitem.headline: CBOT soyoil ends sharply higher, meal mostly down.

text.p: CBOT soyoil futures ended sharply higher on Tuesday, lifted by forecasts for hot, dry weather in the U.S. Midwest with old crop up on a correction from Monday's weak performance, traders said.
Soymeal ended mixed with some new crop months up weather.

"It's probably just a correction in the product values on ideas the oil had been left behind more than was warranted," said Mario Balletto, analyst with Merrill Lynch. "Fundamentally, there's nothing in terms of anything new."
Meteorologists forecast a week of hot, dry weather for the U.S. Midwest with no rains expected until Friday.
Persistent hot, dry summer weather can cause heat and moisture stress, cutting yield potential, traders said.

Traders said the market ignored bearish long-term forecasts by the National Weather Service. The NWS six- to 10-day outlook called for above normal rainfall and normal to below normal temperatures for much of the Midwest July 20-24.
Soymeal ended $3.00 per ton lower to $0.50 higher with August down $3.00 at $251.90 a ton. Soyoil closed 0.46 to 0.30 cent per lb with August up 0.36 at 22.79 cents.
Commercials were noted buyers of soyoil. Traders said Produce Grain bought 1,200 lots soyoil on the day.
ADM and Cargill Inc sold 400 lots each, traders said.
In soymeal, Merrill Lynch sold 300 lots December and 100 August and bought 200 December. Cargill Inc bought 300 August and 100 December while Term Commodities sold 300 August.
Soymeal volume was estimated by CBOT at 28,000 lots, compared with Monday's actual volume of 24,406 lots. Soyoil volume was pegged at 25,000 lots, against Monday's 23,485.
